instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the development of the intelligent system approach for predicting soil properties?
Output: Portable MIR spectroscopy was used in the related study.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the development of the intelligent system approach for predicting soil properties?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in the development of the intelligent system approach for predicting soil properties were machine learning techniques.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine learning techniques in predicting soil properties?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the machine learning techniques in predicting soil properties was the root mean squared error (RMSE).

instruction: What machine learning techniques were used in the development of the intelligent system approach for predicting soil properties based on portable MIR spectroscopy data?
Output: The machine learning techniques used in the development of the intelligent system approach for predicting soil properties based on portable MIR spectroscopy data were Gaussian process regression (GPR), Random Forest (RF), M5 rules, Bagging and Decision Trees, and Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR).

instruction: How does the performance of the GPR technique compare to other machine learning techniques in predicting soil properties using portable MIR spectroscopy data?
Output:
The performance of the GPR technique in predicting soil properties using portable MIR spectroscopy data was found to be superior to other machine learning techniques. In the study, various machine learning techniques including Gaussian process regression (GPR), Random Forest (RF), M5 rules, Bagging and Decision Trees, were compared with traditional Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR). While all the models showed satisfactory performance, GPR stood out as the best performing algorithm according to statistical tests. 

Specifically, GPR outperformed PLSR in predicting clay, exchangeable sodium (Na+), and cation exchange capacity (CEC) with root mean squared error differences of -0.27%, -0.40%, and -0.63 cmol(+) kg(-1), respectively. This indicates that GPR provided more accurate predictions for these soil properties compared to PLSR. 

Overall, the study demonstrated that the GPR technique is the most suitable and reliable approach for predicting soil properties using portable MIR spectroscopy data.
